reviewText: We loved it because the characters in this movie really brought out the best in each other. Aunt Bam was really good and the story about how a family can be so divided on past unresolved issues and then wonder why their current lives are so far apart from one another was portrayed brilliantly. Nice little twists as well. The dramatic points could easily have been stand alone pieces but were succinctly understated. We really enjoyed this film and watched it a second time a few days later. Glad we purchased this movie.

reviewText: As much as I've loved the character "Madea" over the years, she's a little more over-the-top (more silly) with every successive film, especially this one.  Here the silliness begins as Madea drives her car into a fast food restaurant that doesn't serve her favorite breakfast combo meal after a certain time in the morning.  Although this film wouldn't have been as funny without Madea, I do think that the character could've been toned down a bit.  The film stars some fresh faces and familiar ones--the rapper Bow-wow (who's performance is surprisingly great) and the regularly underrated veteran actress Loretta Devine.  Nevertheless, I loved the lessons Tyler Perry was trying to impart...those many life lessons we grow up with but oftentimes lay to the wayside when it comes to our own children.  This is a good family film where the take-away is to remember to care for and about each other, and that we're only as sick as our secrets.

reviewText: It seems that every year Tyler Perry has a new film that comes out and with this one, he should have slowed down and took his time because this has seemed rush. This movie doesn't have the magic like some of his earlier works like Diary of a Mad Black Woman & The Family That Prays.This movie has all of Tyler's other films all wrapped up into this one and basically sloppily done. Lets see Bow Wow selling drugs is similar to Keshia Knight Pulliam being a prostitute in Madea Goes to Jail, the sister rivalry is just like Taraji P. Henson & Sanaa Lathan in The Family That Prays, the marriage problems is just like Why Did I Get Married films, baby mama drama is almost like Diary of a Mad Black Woman, kids with a smart mouth is like I Can Do Bad All By Myself. Throw in Brown from Meet the Browns, and Madea from all the other films she starred in and you got Madea's Big Happy Family.Instead of hiring all these new actors to play Madea's family it would have been better if Tyler had elaborated on Madea's part of the family that we seen in earlier films. Like how Kimberly Elise and Shemar Moore's characters are doing, the characters from Madea's Family Reunion film, none of them have been mentioned at all in films that starred Madea. I'm far more interested in those characters than the characters that were in this film because they are just recycled characters from Tyler's earlier films. What about the child that Madea was a foster mother to that was played by Keke Palmer, I mean what is going on with them.Instead cliched characters, snooty sister, men being owned by their wives, ghetto baby mama, a pot head, and Brown being unfunny as usual. Using Maury as a comedy is a big no. Maury's show sucks with the 1000% sure and running off stage, that's not funny, that's just tasteless.Tyler should slow down and put more thoughts, character development, and great storytelling instead of having a family tragedy that brings everyone together in the end. That's been done so many times in films.

reviewText: I have to say, I for one, enjoy most of Tyler Perry's, somewhat contrived, and repetitive, but mostly thought provoking movies. My guilty pleasure, but I don't feel guilty about anything, so call it a "pleasure" or comfort food type movie.I was a bit surprised to see two, somewhat hip black kids, playing videogames, on their stomachs, using joy sticks?  Huh?  Now that was sloppy research and prop supply.  Last time I checked, joy sticks were used with a computer, way back in the mid-80's.  Not on a television, in the 2010's.  What game were they playing?  Pong?  That was just ridiculous and completely out of place.I know, I'm probably one of the few to notice or comment, but I had to say something. Please, for goodness sake, do what everyone else does next time!:  give them a PS3 or 360 look-a-like type controller, and make it look natural. And while you're at it, feel free to add sound effects.  Those were missing too.  And don't use stupid beeps and boops of the games in the 80's either.  Use true life, modern day video game sound effects. I'm sure your sound man can whip up something, that you won't have to pay rights for.I know this review might get low reviews, but I'm willing to take one for the team, to get my point across.  Some other geek, or technie noticed this too, so feel free to comment. Ohh, and all you who don't put yourself in this category, feel free to comment, and how it doesn't matter, but it does.  It really does.
summary: Two Kids Playing Videogames Using Joy Sticks?!!!!!!

reviewText: MADEA'S BIG HAPPY FAMILY (Dir. Tyler Perry, 2011, 107 minutes) proves one thing among several: if there is a William Shakespeare of the late 20th and early 21st century, it is Tyler Perry. Perry again appears as the frightening, monolithic Southern matriarch Madea Simmons, this time saddled with a tragedy that she naturally is too rambunctious to take lying down.When Madea's niece Shirley (the DIVINE Loretta Devine) is diagnosed, again, with serious cancer and given only weeks to live, she desires to assemble her children to tell them. When one is confronted by a Tyler Perry film, one knows to expect grating, emotional, drop-dead hilarious highjinks and this film delivers like no other I have seen. While I am sadly confined to only bits of Perry's genius -Tyler Perry's Meet The Browns,Madea Goes to Jail (The Tyler Perry Collection)- and don't know the entire story, I can recommend this as the funniest, saddest and most cogent film of Perry's.This all began withMadea's Family Reunion (Full Screen Edition)nearly 10 years ago (to my shame, I do not know anything about the Madea plays Perry has done or if they are available on DVD). Just concentrate on the films. They are insane, too funny to begin to be described and the one-liners are among the best comedy ever written.With the talents of the GORGEOUS and charming Bow Wow, a vital cameo by Maury Povich as himself, Cassi Davis, Shannon Kane, Isaiah Mustafa, Natalie Desselle Reid, Rodney Perry, the fantastic Tamela J. Mann as Cora Madea's daughter, David Mann ... and a whole bunch of hilarious folks I am too lazy and good-for-nothing to list here.If you have never seen or even heard of Madea (HOW can that be?!) see this film. In the words of Madea, You'd be a #$%^#!!??#$@^%&*& if you didn't.

reviewText: Just like many others, I too have had issues with some of Tyler Perry's movies and their depiction of black people.  However, funny is funny and Madea's Big Happy Family is flat out, laugh out loud funny.  The movie is well cast and well acted and many sequences effectively serve as social commentary.  Bow Wow in particular does well and demonstrates that he has come a long way since his first movie role.  As per usual, Loretta Devine adds class, style and substance to every film she has a part in.  Even TP as Madea appears to be less of a caricature in this film than in her other forays onto the big screen.  All-in-all, MBHP demonstrates that TP is growing as both a film-maker and story-teller.  I would recommend that people, especially those who are critical of Mr. Perry give it a try.

reviewText: Shirley (Loretta Devine) has been fighting cancer for about seven years, but it hasn't gotten her down. She's thanking God for the days she's had and accepting what is to come. All she wants more than anything is to sit down at a nice dinner with her adult children so they will all be together when she tells them the sad news.Madea's Big Happy Family sends much needed messages to husbands and wives, battling siblings, bad behind children, teenage single parents... any family dealing with sensitive issues, disrespecting each other and keeping secrets. There were `zany' parts in this movie - I can deal with zany for a little bit, but it gets on my nerves after a while - but there were also quite a few touching and eye-opening moments. The first time I saw this movie was in the theater. The Opening Credits shows like an animated mini-movie, so I was entertained even before the movie began. My main thought after the movie was that families really need to stop wasting time and taking each other for granted. A sequel would be nice, because I would like to know what happens with Kimberly's (Shannon Kane) situation.Favorite Character: Aunt Bam (Cassi Davis) - she's honest, bold and witty.Favorite Line: You don't feel bad for me. You feel bad for somebody who don't know Jesus.Favorite Scenes: Something's Got to Give/Look in the MirrorI appreciate the fact that Mr. Perry brings humor into people's lives. I've always seen the ability to make others laugh as one of the most precious gifts a person could have. This world needs more happiness; I know I could use a good laugh daily. Mr. Perry has created a character or two who can be a little over the top - zany - but as a whole I enjoy his work. Laughter is only one thing his films bring to my life. What I like most is the lessons he teaches with his movies. When she's not acting crazy and going off on people, Madea shares words of wisdom that can reach my heart like a good Bible teaching. (Don't ask her about The Bible, though, because she is not very good at interpreting Scripture). And even when Madea doesn't play a part in a movie, somebody is going to say something thought-provoking. I don't have many of Mr. Perry's plays on DVD, but I do own every movie. I will continue to support his work.
Title: N/A

reviewText: A lot of people don't understand why I would enjoy a Tyler Perry Movie. Well, Madea is the reason. I happen to think that Madea is one of the best created characters ever. She has wisdom, sass, and isn't afraid to kick yo' ass. LOL.As usual, Madea ends up in the middle of everyone business... solving everyone's problems... except her own.Besides Madea, Shirley has gotten bad news... and it's heartbreaking to watch her story unfold. You physically, emotionally, and mentally feel Shirley's pain. It tears at your heart and festers in your soul. Never say Tyler Perry can't write a story cause... DAMN he can write a story.I have yet to see a Tyler Perry movie I did not like... and this one is no different. Can't wait for the next movie Madea is in.

reviewText: I like the Madea movies. Generally they have always entertained me. This movie is definitely not without its good bits, some parts had me laughing out loud, but the story itself was sketchy and some of the characters coming across as rather cardboard.Some of the points of the story are touched upon but never really explored and explained. I would have liked to see a couple of flashbacks of Byron and Sabrina, to show how they hooked up in the first place. This movie would have greatly benefited from more backstory. And the thing between Cora and her father in this film was unneeded and didn't really add to the story. One of the good things to be taken from this story is that you should raise your child right. Amen to that!Long story short, if you're a Madea/Tyler Perry fan, you should enjoy this because it is not without its fun moments. However, if you've never seen a Madea movie, I recommend 'Madea Goes to Jail' or 'Madea's Family Reunion'.

reviewText: I must say that I was surprised to see another Tyler Perry Movie out so soon.I feel that this one was rushed BUT it HIT the SPOT.  If you are in a FAMILY with an AILING PARENT it may do you JUSTICE to see this movie.  Especially if you have a MOM who REALLY SACRIFICED for you.  If you do, DEFINITELY SEE this movie!!After you see this movie, if anyone applies --- get THAT FAMILY to WATCH it with you with no distractions.  I SAW someone so clearly in the movie and they MUST see it.  The MOVIE was humorous yet helpful for ME.  I plan to WATCH it with those that I feel it applies too.  They may be in such denial that they really don't see themselves, if so, don't worry someone will tell them or leave them with alone to deal with their sad little life.This ONE really HITS HOME!!!  Definitely rent, BUY especially if NEEDED!!  IT's HARSH but there is SOME TRUTH!!CONS:  There were definite stereotypes but one was indeed OVERKILL and that was the WEED smoker.  She came out of Ella Payne character and she played her ROLE WELL but it was scripted for OVER KILLLLLLLLLLLLL!!  Sorry, couldn't relate Tyler, every afro american doesn't have a weed head that blatantly FIRES up at EVERY Opportunity!!  That was a HOT Mess but she played the part extremely well.If you are all into the FAM, I suggest that you buy otherwise RENT for a GOOD LAUGH with a couple of friends (BYOB)!!RATED 4 for the OVERKILL(s)!!

reviewText: When Tyler Perry first came on the Hollywood scene I loved him and his memorable characters. However, the more movies he makes the less I like him or the stories he tells. Madea has long been my most favorite character that he has created, but in the last few movies her star has started to shine less and make me more bored than anything. Many of his newer movies have the same feel and story to tell, just in a different way, and his characters (especially in this movie) aren't all that likable. I don't think he's really accessing his writing talent very well, this was just a big collection of scenes that reminded me of so many other scenes in his previous movies. Disappointed.
summary: I'm Starting to Get Bored with Tyler Perry Movies

reviewText: This movie is based on a play that was written shortly after Mr. Perry's mother has passed. reviewText: Updated con: I was on the train coming home from work when three obnoxiously loud little girls all started screaming "Byre-eee-een." Great. I thought I was in the clear unless someone named Byron was around. Apparently there doesn't even have to be a Byron around for somebody to feel the need to be annoying enough to mock that incredibly loud, ghetto, annoying "baby momma" in the film.Cons: I know Tyler Perry gets a lot of criticism for how men are portrayed in many of his other movies so I think he tried to make up for it in this one. I get why he would want to show the father who is trying to be a positive, responsible person for his kids, and the husbands who are trying to make their marriages work. However, every single woman in the entire script was incredibly negative: greedy mother; gold-digging girlfriend; nosey weed-smoking roommate; prudish hostile wife; loud-talking unappreciative wife; a mother who appears to be nice but we find out a secret about her (I won't spoil it, but if you've seen Tyler Perry's other movies it's not difficult to guess what it is); and Madea is driving through restaurants hopping the counters. I like Madea. I think she's amusing. But the rest of these women (minus Cora, who didn't have anything different about her plot in this story as she had in others--still thinking Mr. Brown is her father and being "surprised" when she finds out he's not) were repulsive. I can't quite tell whether Tyler Perry was trying to send a message to sistas saying, "Too many of you all act like this" or is he really just angry with the state of women in his own life. The downside is that the characters aren't so far-fetched that I can't think of someone I know now who could play each of these roles. It was draining to see that nobody seemed to have much going for themselves outside of the men. And speaking of men, I can't think of ONE guy who would take this much abuse from these women. There was way too much "knights in distress" going on. This movie made the guys in the "Twilight" films seem strong and independent, and those guys were super sprung. And as for any guy whose name is Byron, I feel so bad for you. There's going to be that one woman in your life who's going to think it's funny to constantly mock that name. I wanted to reach through the screen and punch the trouble-making mother in the mouth. Gawd, she was so annoying. But again, I know women like her...just like her, so that was even more creepy.The plot was about the same as any other plot. We have a drug dealer, someone who is molested, marriages that aren't working, and even threw in a couple particularly trashy Maury Povich episodes arguing about who is the father of some children. This is in addition to another "surprise" kid. The stereotypes were in full effect in this film. Even the head mother was annoying. She just kept letting her kids run over her, and it seemed like Madea was the only one who had some kind of power to make people sit down and shut up. The rest of the women had enough strength to be brutal to the guys and kinda disrespectful to the head mother, but nobody really seemed to care.Pros: Bow Wow's performance in the film was REALLY good. I've enjoyed him in "Roll Bounce," "Lottery Ticket" and a couple other flicks, but he did such an impressive job in this film. The only problem is that the film was so awful that I think his performance will be overlooked.I'm not a fan of Spike Lee. Period. I think he's incredibly rude and mean-spirited (met him in person), so it pains me to say I absolutely agree with him about Tyler Perry films. This is by far the worst movie he's done, and I have been a Tyler Perry supporter for years. But it's time to write about something else. I could predict this movie from beginning to end from the first 10 minutes, and I never cracked a smile.

reviewText: I watched this at the suggestion of someone else. I had no idea who Tyler Perry was and hadn't seen any Madea material before. I was surprised that it was a play. I wasn't expecting that and wasn't looking forward to it actually. I also didn't like the negative and stereotypical portrayals of all the characters at first. I am glad I gave it a chance. Two thirds of the way through, the light clicked on and I started to love it. It's preachy, but it's done with love. The music totally supports the message and makes it heartfelt. Everybody needs a Madea in the family to set them straight. Love the message. Love the movie/play. I am a new fan.

reviewText: Like most of Tyler Perry's films, this one has a great deal of comedy and banter, but also helps a modern family deal with their issues.A mother discovers she has terminal illness and attempts to gather her family together to tell them of her short time, as well as to put aside their differences and spend quality time with each other.  Things do not go as planned, and many hurts come out.  However in the midst of the dysfunction and sadness, the family does come together in the crisis and attempts to face some of their problems and sadness.Critics complain the humor is too present and lowbrow -- however I find, like in Shakespeare's tragedies, the use of humor takes some of the sting away from the horror and brings a balance to the production, without diminishing the quality of either.  I thought this movie was easier to handle than some of Perry's other films ("Diary of a Mad Black Woman" in particular) due to the use of his humor here.

reviewText: I'm surpised at the postive reviews. This isn't one of Tyler Perry's best. And I'm more surprised that it came out in 2010. If it was one of his earlier movies it would be easier to justify how badly edited and low budget it looks. Some of the scenes go on longer than than they need to. And it has a spoofish quality to it which lacks the balance of his other movies. Maybe he was trying to give a comedic "Brady Bunch" twist to the usual stories about black families. But it doesn't come off well. A lot of things are thrown in there without any rationale (like Madea going crazy and driving her car through the window of a burger joint just because the server wouldn't serve her properly).The themes explored are quite depressing- like the (largely passive) mother suffering from cancer and the vitriolic sisters always at each other's and their husband's throats. There is no real resolution in the end, except Madea giving a big speech to all the family members. The advise given is quite obvious and lacks the wisdom and insight that her character displays in other movies. Some of the characters are uneccesary and just seem to be a parody of themselves in trying to address black stereotypes. I can understand why Spike Lee and others might criticize it. There doesn't seem to be much of a moral here except "family stick together even if you are dysfunctional" and "men stand up to your women". It seems like an attempt to explore the men's side of the story in relationships. But it doesn't do so convincingly. The stand out performances for me were Lil Bow wow and Teyana Taylor. Lil bow wow was execellent and believable as the frustrated young father. If I didn't know he was a rapper, I could easily believe he was an actor. Teyana Taylor stole the show as the baby mama from hell. I thought her scenes were some of the funniest.
summary: not as good as some of his other family movies

reviewText: Tyler Perry must be getting lazy. This movie is a patchwork of storylines from previous movies, and the characters are so over the top that I actually found myself wincing. There are no shades of gray in this movie--the characters are either irritating, bickering ingrates or noble heroes. I've generally been a fan of Tyler Perry's movies, but he's losing his touch. Madea's character is little more than a cartoon, and Brown may be the most irritating character since JarJar Binks. How many time can they mispronounce words and it still be funny? When you have to resort to Maury Povich for a finale, you know something's going wrong. This movie is a total disaster.
